description.narrative: The project Opening Pathways to Justice for the Poor aims to provide increased access to justice in formal court and mediation for socially excluded and marginalised women, men and children in particular workers, persons with disabilities and ethnic minorities and thereby contribute towards reducing poverty, inequality and discrimination. The main problem of access to justice for the poor is entrenched social norms, profound power imbalances and poor governance practices. As a result the formal justice system remains more responsive to the rich and powerful, while being inaccessible, daunting and cumbersome for women, men and children who are poor and marginalized. Outcome Indicator 1: Increased access to justice for poor, socially excluded and marginalized women, men and children through informal justice and increasingly responsive formal justice system; Target: 1) 70 % of cases litigated, disputes settled are successful (60% in 2016). Major targeted outputs are 1) 95, 000 cases litigated (70,000 in 2016); 2) 40, 600 disputes settled through mediation (30500 in 2016). Outcome indicator 2: Enabling environment for workers around their rights and entitlements and safety standards at workplace. Target: 65% of workers are able to claim their rights and entitlements (60% in 2016). Main targeted output is 375 cases and mediations with successful outcomes for workers (75 in 2016). Outcome Indication 3: Legal and Policy framework strengthened through advocacy for reforms and practice level changes. Target: 4 legal and policy reform. Major targeted outputs are:  1) 10 PIL cases filed or steps taken and judgments/orders received (2 in 2016); 2) 15 improved laws/ policies/ practices/ institutional reforms on justice and human rights (3 in 2016). The project is implementing 19 districts across the country along with High Court and Supreme Court of Bangladesh.
This project mainly contributes to results within Fulfilment of human rights commitments. Results will be reported later in the Global Civsam grant period 2016-2020
